item.title: Evaluation Expert (Category II)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Evaluation of the Biodiversity Programme

The main objectives of the evaluation are to provide the relevant external co-operation services of the European Union, the partner government and, when appropriate, the wider public with:

  • an overall independent assessment of the past performance of the Coastal, Marine and Island Specific Bio-diversity Management in ESA-IO Coastal States, paying particularly attention to the results of the project against its objectives;
  • key lessons and recommendations in order to improve current and future action

The focus of the evaluation should be on the effectiveness and efficiency of the implementation as these seem to be the nature of the challenges that the programme faces.

Furthermore, while this is an intermediate evaluation where conclusions are sought to improve the intervention under way it would be important also to analyse the conceptualisation of the programme to obtain good practices to be transferred to other future programmes in the same or different domains.

An analysis to the recurrent delays would help the Indian Ocean Commission and the European Union Delegation in Mauritius to take into account the identified issues when identifying future programmes.

Also, it would be important to analyse how best to answer to the existing issues and to identify if these answers would respond only to the identified issues on the programme or they could be used in a more systematic way.

Key expert: Evaluation Expert (Category II)

Education

  • M.Sc or M.A. or equivalent in Business Administration or similar, or Environmental Studies or similar, or Development Studies or similar;
  • Has a strong passive and active knowledge of English and French

** General professional experience**

  • Has managed at least a three-year programme or project financed by the European Union in the last 12 years, preference will be given to multi-country programmes or projects.
  • Has evaluated at least 3 programmes financed by the European Union

Specific professional experience

  • Has at least three years experience in environmental studies or similar, preference will be given to experience in biodiversity sector
  • Preference will be given to professional experience acquired in the Western Indian Ocean region.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to anju_english@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.title: Senior Expert in Economic Integration and/or Trade with experience in EC Evaluation
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Final Evaluation EPA and CDB Standby Facilities

Systematic and timely evaluation of its programmes and activities is an established priority of the European Commission. The focus of evaluations is on the assessment of achievements, the quality and the results of Actions in the context of an evolving cooperation policy with an increasing emphasis on result-oriented approaches. From this perspective, evaluations should look for evidence of why, whether or how these results are linked to the EU intervention and seek to identify the factors driving or hindering progress.

Evaluations should provide an understanding of the cause and effects links between inputs and activities, and outputs, outcomes and impacts. Evaluations should serve accountability, decision making, learning, and management purposes.

The main objectives of this evaluation are to provide the relevant services of the European Union, the interested stakeholders with:

  • an overall independent assessment of the performance of the Action 2012/FED/299-293/EPA Stand by Facility for Capacity Building and the Action 2012/FED/299-636/ CSME Standby Facility for Capacity Building paying particular attention to its results measured against its objectives;
  • key lessons and recommendations in order to inform future Actions.

In particular, this evaluation will serve to determine to which extent the Facilities have achieved their objectives, and contributed to strengthen CSME and EPA implementation at the national level. It will also look at how the Actions have contributed to increasing ownership of the CSME and EPA processes through the delivery of tangible results. The performance of the management and approval process should also be assessed.

The evaluation should make recommendations for future Actions, in particular: are such facilities the best vehicle to assist Member States with implementation at the national level and if not, what would be the alternative; if renewed, what would be the best governance and monitoring mechanism. It should be assessed whether a demand driven facility (as opposed to allocations pre-identified per Member States) would be a better to way to ensure efficiency of the use of resources, with recommendations as to how accompany those Member States with fewer capacities. The evaluation should recommend a strategy which would assist with prioritising the areas with most urgent need at the national level.

The main users of this evaluation will be the European Commission, the CARIFORUM Directorate and the CDB, the CSME Unit and CARIFORUM Member States.

Senior Expert in Economic Integration and/or Trade with experience in EC Evaluation

Qualifications and skills:

  • At least Master’s Degree in Economics, Business Administration, International Affairs or equivalent in its absence not less than three (3) years' relevant experience in addition to the 12 years professional experience required below:

Professional experience:

  • 12 Years in international development, in particular, areas related to economic integration and Trade
  • Experience with EC evaluation would be an advantage.

Common requirements:

  • Full working knowledge of English and excellent report writing is required for both experts. At least 1 expert should have a good command of spoken Spanish.
  • The composition of the team of experts should be balanced to enable complete coverage of the different aspects of project evaluation (evaluation methods and techniques) as set out in these terms of reference, including cross-cutting issues.
  • The team as a whole should possess a sound level of knowledge of and/or experience in regional integration processes and regional development issues

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to anju_english@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.author: Penny Buckle

Final Evaluation EPA and CDB Standby Facilities

Systematic and timely evaluation of its programmes and activities is an established priority of the European Commission. The focus of evaluations is on the assessment of achievements, the quality and the results of Actions in the context of an evolving cooperation policy with an increasing emphasis on result-oriented approaches. From this perspective, evaluations should look for evidence of why, whether or how these results are linked to the EU intervention and seek to identify the factors driving or hindering progress.

The main objectives of this evaluation are to provide the relevant services of the European Union, the interested stakeholders with:

  • an overall independent assessment of the performance of the Action 2012/FED/299-293/EPA Stand by Facility for Capacity Building and the Action 2012/FED/299-636/ CSME Standby Facility for Capacity Building paying particular attention to its results measured against its objectives;
  • key lessons and recommendations in order to inform future Actions.

In particular, this evaluation will serve to determine to which extent the Facilities have achieved their objectives, and contributed to strengthen CSME and EPA implementation at the national level. It will also look at how the Actions have contributed to increasing ownership of the CSME and EPA processes through the delivery of tangible results. The performance of the management and approval process should also be assessed.

The evaluation should make recommendations for future Actions, in particular: are such facilities the best vehicle to assist Member States with implementation at the national level and if not, what would be the alternative; if renewed, what would be the best governance and monitoring mechanism. It should be assessed whether a demand driven facility (as opposed to allocations pre-identified per Member States) would be a better to way to ensure efficiency of the use of resources, with recommendations as to how accompany those Member States with fewer capacities. The evaluation should recommend a strategy which would assist with prioritising the areas with most urgent need at the national level.

The main users of this evaluation will be the European Commission, the CARIFORUM Directorate and the CDB, the CSME Unit and CARIFORUM Member States.

Senior Expert in Economic Integration and/or Trade with experience in EC Project Design & Development

Qualifications and skills:

  • At least Master’s Degree in Economics, Business Administration, International relations or equivalent.
  • OR in its absence not less than three (3) years' relevant experience in addition to the 12 years professional experience required below

Professional experience:

  • 12 Years in international development, in particular, areas related to economic integration/ and or Trade
  • 8 Years project/program monitoring and evaluation
  • Prior experience in Project Cycle Management (PCM), in particular EC project design and development.
  • Must possess a high level of fluency in English (spoken and written).

Knowledge of the EU/CARIFORUM EPA and/or the CSME will be an advantage.

Experience with EU funded programmes for the Caribbean will be an advantage.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to anju_english@dai.com

item.title: Two Category III (Junior) Evaluation Experts
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Evaluation of EU Cooperation with Armenia

The overall engagement with Armenia should be taken into consideration in the analysis, including agreements, the co-operation framework and any other official commitments. To the extent possible, the evaluation should distinguish the results obtained through the various EU instruments used in Armenia. Interventions funded by other donors (including i.e. IFIs, UN organisations, bil-lateral agencies and international organisations) at the sector level cannot be part of the evaluation scope – unless they are co-financed, including blending, by the EU. However, the coherence and complementarity between these interventions and the EU cooperation strategy evaluated must be examined.

More specifically, the evaluation will assess:

  • The relevance and coherence of European Union’s co-operation strategy and programmes in the period 2010- mid-2017; This assessment should be done based on a dynamic approach looking for example at issues such as the extent to which the EU support has been responsive to the changes in the socio-economic context of Armenia.
  • The implementation of the European Union’s co-operation, focusing on impact, sustainability, effectiveness and efficiency for the period 2010- mid-2017. The evaluation should keep its focus broad and take also into account implementation of activities approved prior to 2010 but implemented during the evaluation period, as appropriate, as well as the new programming for the period 2017– 2020
  • The consistency between programming and implementation.
  • The value added of the European Union’s interventions (at both strategic and implementation levels).
  • The coordination and complementarity of the European Union’s interventions with other donors' interventions and coherence between the European Union’s interventions and policies that are likely to affect the partner country/region. The latter should include an assessment of the extent the programmes, financed by the EU, are coherent with the objectives set in agreement with Armenia.
  • The coordination and coherence of the various types of cooperation (Bilateral, Regional and Thematic instruments). This should include an assessment of the “fitness for purpose” of the tools/instruments relative to the context of Armenia and efficiency of the procedures used.

Two Category III (Junior) Evaluation Experts

The evaluation team should have the following demonstrated experience and expertise:

  • Working knowledge of EU external action policies, and specifically of the EU Neighbourhood policy, and their implementation modalities
  • Working knowledge of the European Union’s co-operation with Armenia
  • Working knowledge of the international aid and development effectiveness agenda and principles, as well as have good knowledge of cross cutting issues, especially gender mainstreaming, and e.g. of Global Partnership for effective development co-operation (Busan)
  • Evaluation methods and techniques in general and, preferably, of evaluation in the field of external relations and development cooperation; in particular the team needs to demonstrate experience in analytical methods which can evaluate change, and which can evaluate contribution.

Be able to cover the following fields:

  • rule of law and democratisation;
  • public administration reform;
  • public finance management;
  • economic infrastructure development;
  • human capital development, socio-economic reform and sustainable development;
  • Integrated border management and migration;
  • communication/visibility/PR;
  • civil society development;

  • private sector development, trade and investment, market and regulatory reform.

  • Working knowledge of the EU budget support modality

  • Quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis

  • The team leader should have excellent communication, team co-ordination, presentation and proven report writing and editing skills in English. (S)he should have the experience of carrying out at least two complex evaluations as the team leader.

  • The evaluation team should have an excellent command of English – both spoken and written – and the ability to function at a high level in Armenian. Working knowledge of Russian would be an advantage.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to aurelie_durand@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.title: Expert(e) Senior, de catégorie II, en Communication et Media
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Renforcement de la culture de la protection des données a caractère personnel au Maroc

Renforcer le niveau de la protection des données à caractère personnel au sens des exigences de l'Acquis et des bonnes pratiques européennes. En particulier : Evaluer la portée de la nouvelle règlementation européenne sur la protection des données à caractère personnel, préparer un plan d’action indicatif pour sa mise en œuvre et développer des actions d’information et d’éducation numérique.

Projet duree: 18 mois

Expert(e) Senior, de catégorie II, en Communication et Media (71 h/j)

Qualifications et compétences

  • Diplôme universitaire supérieur, niveau Master, en communication/information ou diplôme équivalent et pertinent par rapport aux objectifs du contrat ;
  • Une expérience professionnelle de 3 ans dans le domaine de l’information ou la communication institutionnelle au sein d’une entreprise ou d’une institution publique en plus de celle indiquée comme expérience professionnelle générale, pourra compenser l’absence de Master ;

Expérience professionnelle générale :

  • Au moins six ans d’expérience en conseil, conception et/ou mise en œuvre de programmes et supports d’information/communication au sein d’administrations publiques, services publics ou institutions d’appui aux entreprises, organisations professionnelles ou associations.

Expérience professionnelle spécifique :

  • Au moins 2 ans d’expérience en économie numérique, Internet et/ou traitement des données, acquise au sein d’entreprises privées ou publiques.

Connaissance linguistique :

  • Très bonne maîtrise du français
  • Bonne maîtrise de l'arabe constitue un atout

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Veronica_hernandez-castilla@dai.com

item.title: Category II: Economic/Business expert
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Drafting a Feasibility Study for Establishment of Science and Technology Park

The overall objective of the project is to improve the current innovation ecosystem in the country by strengthening the cooperation among academia, industry and government.

The project shall develop a comprehensive Feasibility study and Action plan for the establishment and operation of a Science and Technology Park (STP) aiming to strengthen the country’s innovation capacities.

Expert category II: Economic/business expert (40 working days)

Education

  • Education of at least Master Degree Academic level, in Economic or Business Administration, or general professional experience of 3 (three) years above the minimum general professional experience requested below.

General professional experience

  • At least 6 years of general professional experience in economics or business administration in preparation of business models/plans and/or cost-benefit analysis.

Specific professional experience

  • Experience in at least two (2) project for preparation of cost-benefit analysis for construction of science or technology parks, or economic and industrial zones.

Language Skills:

  • Fluency in English, both written and spoken. Knowledge of the Macedonian language is an asset.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to gabriela_georgieva@dai.com

item.title: AWP 2 Projects Review
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is “to strengthen government’s capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economy”. The immediate objective is “implementation of priority policy actions from the GoV’s Action Plan to enhance Vietnam’s capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)”.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work plan’s implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Program’s level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.

item.title: Health Program M&E
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Program 2013 Performance and Quality Mapping Exercise
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: AusAID’s PNG Program is looking to improve its performance and quality (P&Q) standards and systems. The purpose of this project was to map the PNG Program’s current P&Q capacity and systems, to address the risk of AusAID being unable to demonstrate results for its increased investments in PNG over the next four years. Over the last several years, the PNG Program has undertaken a number of M&E assessments and reviews which have identified key strengths and challenges within the program. This project was intended to pick up where these assessments left off. Through a desk review and consultations with sector teams, the Review Team were to distil key P&Q risks and issues for the PNG Program. The Review Team’s brief included the provision of recommendations on priority activities to support sector approaches to M&E, strengthen the Program’s ability to collect evidence, provide critical analysis and report on results.

item.title: Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
AusAID required a consultant to assist with the development and finalisation of its Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework. Development of a humanitarian monitoring and evaluation framework is a key commitment outlined in AusAID’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy (HAP) and its associated Implementation Plan. In line with the agency focus on results reporting, the HAP and HAP Implementation Plan commit AusAID to develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to support the initial performance assessment framework contained within the HAP and AusAID annual reporting under the Comprehensive Aid Policy Framework.

The key objective of this assignment was to build the Humanitarian program’s capacity for monitoring and reporting results by:

  • In consultation with AusAID’s Humanitarian team, redraft and finalise the Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework, to ensure it provides a platform to:
  • Track implementation of key commitments in Australia’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy; and,
  • Establish a set of measurable humanitarian performance indicators (in addition to the two CAPF indicators) to enable AusAID to track achievements, lessons learned and to report on the results achieved from AusAID’s humanitarian work.

item.title: Review of Pacific Forum Compact Reporting
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: The purpose of the assignment was to examine country views of aid effectiveness and regional organisations expressed through Forum Compact reporting, particularly peer review of Forum Island Countries’ national development plan processes. The services provided included the preparation of a think piece which outlines key aid effectiveness issues arising from country reporting under the Compact reporting and discusses options for addressing these issues.

item.title: Health Program M&E Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Study on Community-based Social Protection
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
Poverty and Social Analysis is the process of using and generating evidence on poverty throughout the aid management cycle. Most poverty and social analysis focuses on economic and human capital, but there are two oft neglected elements: voice and influence, and social capital. Yet more and more development practitioners are recognizing the importance of social capital, particularly informal social capital, in preventing and addressing poverty and vulnerability.

This project supported AusAID to explore:

  • the role of informal social capital in the Fijian context and whether it lends itself to fair redistribution of resources and, if so, the ways in which AusAID can engage with local communities to strengthen existing social capital structures
  • how such structures can enable the disempowered and poor to claim their entitlements in the three domains discussed in the PSA framework
  • the potential challenges that can arise from such efforts. For instance, the poorest are often included on less favorable terms within social networks, and have access to fewer and lower-quality networks. Further, we need to better understand how poverty and disempowerment intersect with an absence of informal social capital, the repercussions this has, and the options available for tackling this.

item.title: Provision of a Child Protection Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
For this project HTSPE was contracted to provide a child protection specialist and handle all the associated management and administrative work.

The child protection specialist provided by HTSPE was required to work on an assignment designed to assist the Pacific Division (PACD) to improve its approach to child protection and managing risks to children. AusAID has a number of partners in the Pacific who work with children or come into contact with children through their activities. The AusAID-wide child protection stocktake, conducted in May 2013 found that there are a number of organisations funded by AusAID in the Pacific with a high or very high inherent child protection risk. Consistent with the stocktake report PACD proposes to escalate efforts to ensure partner organisations policies, procedures and practices are in accordance with AusAID’s Child Protection Policy 2013 and to make child protection a more explicit focus of PACD’s risk management system.

item.title: Senior Environment and Biology Expert (Category I)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The Expert 2 is expected to contribute the implementation of all of the related modules and the preparation of both training materials and Training Evaluation Report in the context of related chapter/s.

Qualifications and skills:

  • Master’s degree in Biology, Ecology, Chemistry or other Natural Sciences related to assignment. In the absence of the degree required, at least 17 years of professional experience in the related areas is requested.
  • Good command of both written and spoken English.
  • General professional experience
  • At least 12 years of experience in the sector(s) related to the Lot.

Specific professional experience:

  • At least 3 years of experience in technical and/or scientific fields required for the implementation of the Water Framework Directive and/or Habitat Directive and/or other related Directives.
  • At least 2 river basin management plans experience in terms of setting of environmental objectives and/or setting, design and upgrade of biological monitoring programme and/or execution and assessment of biological monitoring.
  • Experience in development of measures for water pollution reduction and/or improving ecological status, and/or river basin characterisation/analysis will be an asset.
  • Experience in projects related to Integrated Water Resources Management will be an asset.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Agnese_Ortolani@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS
